Skip to contentðŸŽ‰Arrival GuideðŸ§‘â€ðŸŽ“42 PedagogyGet Notion freeðŸ§‘â€ðŸŽ“42 PedagogyOwnerMax MeisingerVerificationExpired 1 month agoTagsEmptyðŸ’¡Here is some useful info to the pedagogy at 42. 
You will get the full information during your Kickoff.ðŸŽ“Curriculum42Heilbronn | Learning ModelOur learning model is based on the innovative program of Ã‰cole 42 from Paris and used in over 32 campuses in more than 20 countries worldwide.https://www.42heilbronn.de/en/curriculum/ðŸƒPace SystemA pace is the timeframe you choose to complete the 42 Common Core. It ranges from 8 to 24 months and determines target dates for each of the 7 milestones. Based on your pace, the system sets a deadline for each milestone, including a final estimated completion date. You can always finish milestones earlier than the deadline and pace up or drop a pace if you donâ€™t manage to finish the projects in time. If you miss the pace 24 deadline, you drop out of 42 Heilbronn.Initial Pace and AttendanceYour initial pace is based on how many hours per week you plan to dedicate to your studies. This sets the expected deadlines for each milestone.
Milestones appear as circles in Intra, showing your progress through the Common Core.Pace MatrixThere are 6 available paces. Each pace defines how many days it takes to reach each milestone:Pace 8Pace 12Pace 15Pace 18Pace 22Pace 24Milestone 081318243045Milestone 13248607288118Milestone 25481101121148178Milestone 390134168201246306Milestone 4141211264316387447Milestone 5212318398478584644Milestone 6244365457548670730ðŸ¥¶FreezesFreeze PolicyFreezes give you extra time if personal challenges come up.
While on freeze, you cannot log in at school or use your Intra account, except to end the freeze early. Use this time to focus on your situation. 
Important: You are not allowed on campus during a freeze.What Happens if You Show UpIf youâ€™re seen on campus during a freeze, youâ€™ll get a warning and be asked to leave. If it happens again, weâ€™ll assume you no longer need the freeze and will end it in the system.window.LOCALE_SETUP=void 0,window.LOCALE_SETUP_P=Promise.resolve()(()=>{try{window.addEventListener("error",(function(e){if(e.target&&(e.target instanceof HTMLScriptElement||e.target instanceof HTMLLinkElement&&"stylesheet"===e.target.rel)){var t=e.target instanceof HTMLScriptElement?"script":"stylesheet",r=e.target.src||e.target.href;console.error("Resource Sentinel noted a failed resource load of type",t,r),fetch("https://http-inputs-notion.splunkcloud.com/services/collector/raw",{method:"POST",headers:{"Content-Type":"text/plain; charset=utf-8",Authorization:"Splunk EA76605A-F565-4B17-A496-34435622A1EB"},mode:"cors",keepalive:!0,body:JSON.stringify({environment:"production",level:"error",from:"resourceSentinel",type:"resourceLoadFailure",error:{message:`Failed to load "${t}" resource`,miscDataString:r}}),priority:"low"}).catch(e=>{console.error("Resource Sentinel failed to send error to Splunk",e)})}}),!0),console.info("Resource Sentinel initialized...")}catch(e){console.error("Resource Sentinel failed to initialize",e)}})()__notion_html_async.push("bootData",null)__notion_html_async.push("ready",!0)__notion_html_async.push("bootReady",true)__notion_html_async.push("serverSidePrefetchDataPending",false)__notion_html_async.push("serverSidePrefetchData",null)__notion_html_async.push("statsigResults",null)__notion_html_async.push("statsigResultsMetadata",null)__notion_html_async.push("requiredRedirectMetadata",{"pageId":"1ff5cefb-e7fa-810d-b1c5-c8f02c8f9a82","requiresRedirect":false})__notion_html_async.push(null,null)

### https://www.notion.so/42heilbronn/Code-of-Conduct-e83f6c1555924573acce902adb6be4eb?pvs=25

**URL:** https://www.notion.so/42heilbronn/Code-of-Conduct-e83f6c1555924573acce902adb6be4eb?pvs=25

**Content:**

Skip to content42 Heilbronn's NotionSearchInboxSharedðŸ“šStudent WikiExplore more of NotionJoin as member to collaborateJoin or create workspaceðŸ“šStudent WikiðŸ¤“RulesðŸ“œCode of ConductEdited Oct 9ðŸ“œCode of ConductOwnerMax MeisingerVerificationUntil January 7, 2026TagsEmptyWe set a few norms, rules and responsibilities that we ask you to adhere to, inspired by the Code of Conduct for Open Source Projects; adopted by more than four thousand open source projects. It is not a comprehensive list of things you can or cannot do. Rather, take it in the spirit in which it is intended â€“ a guide to make 42 Heilbronn a place where you can be and become your best self.We expect students to live by the code of conduct, and also to encourage others to do the same. If you believe someone is violating the code of conduct, point it out to them in a friendly way. If this doesnâ€™t work or you donâ€™t feel comfortable doing so, you can report it to one of the staff members.Be respectful. Number one rule is to always treat your peers, the staff, basically everyone in your life with respect. 42 Heilbronn must be a harassment-free experience for everyone, regardless of level of experience, gender, gender identity and expression, sexual orientation, disability, personal appearance, body size, ethnicity, age, religion or nationality.Be friendly and patient. Not all of us will agree all the time, but disagreement is no excuse for poor behavior and poor manners. You will experience some frustration now and then, but we cannot allow that frustration to turn into personal attacks. We expect you to stay friendly and work it out in a capable and respectful manner. And also be friendly and patient with yourself.Be considerate. You will have to collaborate with a lot of different people, by reviewing otherâ€™s work and/or working in a team. Decisions you make will affect other students, and you should take those consequences into account when making decisions. Be kind to others; we donâ€™t accept insults or putting people down, neither directly, through gossiping, offending facial expressions or gestures.Be open and polite. You will notice quickly that helping your peers makes you a better coder. Do not only wait to be asked for help, but be responsive and proactive. Remember that you are in this together; there is no competition. Harassment and other exclusionary behavior are not acceptable. This includes, but is not limited to:Violent threats or language directed against another personDiscriminatory jokes and languagePosting sexually explicit or violent materialPosting and/or sharing other peopleâ€™s personal informationPersonal insults, especially those using racist, LGBTQ-phobic, or sexist termssexual attention on campusAdvocating for, or encouraging, any of the above behaviorRepeated harassment of others. In general, if someone asks you to stop, then stop.Be understanding. Disagreements, both social and technical, happen all the time and 42 Heilbronn is no exception. It is important that we resolve disagreements and differing views constructively. Remember that we are all different and it is human to make mistakes, and blaming each other doesnâ€™t get us anywhere. Instead, focus on helping to resolve issues and learning from mistakes.Be calm. Remember that you are not the only one behind a computer. If you want to ask someone something, go see them. Calling or shouting is not accepted. Even though clusters are not silent rooms, do not do anything that you would not do in a public place.Please also review our rules for posting on social media / Slack in the next section.window.LOCALE_SETUP=void 0,window.LOCALE_SETUP_P=Promise.resolve()(()=>{try{window.addEventListener("error",(function(e){if(e.target&&(e.target instanceof HTMLScriptElement||e.target instanceof HTMLLinkElement&&"stylesheet"===e.target.rel)){var t=e.target instanceof HTMLScriptElement?"script":"stylesheet",r=e.target.src||e.target.href;console.error("Resource Sentinel noted a failed resource load of type",t,r),fetch("https://http-inputs-notion.splunkcloud.com/services/collector/raw",{method:"POST",headers:{"Content-Type":"text/plain; charset=utf-8",Authorization:"Splunk EA76605A-F565-4B17-A496-34435622A1EB"},mode:"cors",keepalive:!0,body:JSON.stringify({environment:"production",level:"error",from:"resourceSentinel",type:"resourceLoadFailure",error:{message:`Failed to load "${t}" resource`,miscDataString:r}}),priority:"low"}).catch(e=>{console.error("Resource Sentinel failed to send error to Splunk",e)})}}),!0),console.info("Resource Sentinel initialized...")}catch(e){console.error("Resource Sentinel failed to initialize",e)}})()__notion_html_async.push("bootData",{"userId":"284d872b-594c-812b-983e-00023353d1a4","spaceId":"10ec54f0-7d84-413b-b0dd-14cc9a964e80","pageId":"e83f6c15-5592-4573-acce-902adb6be4eb"})__notion_html_async.push("ready",!0)__notion_html_async.push("bootReady",true)__notion_html_async.push("serverSidePrefetchDataPending",false)__notion_html_async.push("serverSidePrefetchData",null)__notion_html_async.push("statsigResults",null)__notion_html_async.push("statsigResultsMetadata",null)__notion_html_async.push("requiredRedirectMetadata",{"pageId":"e83f6c15-5592-4573-acce-902adb6be4eb","requiresRedirect":false})__notion_html_async.push(null,null)

Non-42 or non-coding related posts should have the goal to strengthen the community, and foster mutual and planetary awareness & respect (e.g. issues related to discrimination).Posts should emphasize the human bond between all of us, and be mindful of different views. No matter, which opinion you have - it may be wrong. We never have full perspective.Non 42-related posts should ideally state the motivation of the post. Posts are allowed and encouraged, where people share their emotions, and seek allyship.Disrespectful posts are not allowed, and are subject to deletion. Posts may not use national, racial, gender stereotypes. In order to keep everything functional and last as long as possible, please make sure to handle everything in the right way as following:Do not forcefully power down the computers unless instructed. They are supposed to run 24/7.Do not unplug, move, disassemble, or damage any and all IT resources available at 42 Heilbronn.Do not plug any personal devices into the power outlets below the desks. The Power outlets below the desks in the clusters are off limits.Do not access equipment which you are not authorized to. Both physically and remotely.Do not use identifiers and passwords from another user, with or without their approval.Do not hide your identity or impersonate another user when accessing 42 Heilbronnâ€™s IT resources.Do not use any and all IT resources in a way that can harm other usersâ€™ studies or peacefulness.No food and open containers in the cluster. A closed bottle of water / non alcoholic beverage is tolerated on the floor or in your bag.Make sure that your behavior does not affect other student's ability to work. No shouting, no singing, no music from the speakers, no phone calls in the clusters.Clean up after yourself. Do not leave a mess on workspace desk. You do not have a dedicated working space. All iMacs are for all Students.Leave your workspace tidy so the next person can work on it without having to clean up your mess.Do not use the audio output on the back of the iMac to increase the durability of the devices. Please use an adapter or bluetooth.Do not download or distribute illegal files, warez, pornography on the 42 Network.Until further notice students are allowed to bring their own mice and keyboards from home with the following note:No "Clicky" / Loud Mechanical KeyboardsIf there is an issue caused by your peripherals, we will not provide support whatsoever.If your peripherals end up damaging the equipment on campus, this includes the iMacs, you will be held accountable for it and can be billed for the damage caused on the machine.You are responsible for them. 42 Heilbronn AI Chatbot
A modern, intelligent chatbot designed specifically for 42 Heilbronn students. Built with React, Node.js, and OpenAI integration, it provides instant answers about campus life, coding standards, and student resources.
âœ¨ Features

ðŸ¤– AI-Powered: Uses OpenAI GPT-3.5-turbo for intelligent responses
ðŸŽ¯ 42-Specific: Focused only on 42 Heilbronn topics (redirects general questions to Google)
ðŸ“š Knowledge Base: Comprehensive information scraped from official Notion pages
ðŸ’¬ Modern Chat UI: Beautiful, responsive interface with real-time messaging
ðŸ”„ Auto-Updates: Easy knowledge base updates from Notion content
ðŸ“± Mobile-Friendly: Works perfectly on all devices

ðŸ—ï¸ Project Structure
/
â”œâ”€â”€ client/                    # React Frontend
â”‚   â”œâ”€â”€ src/
â”‚   â”‚   â”œâ”€â”€ components/        # Chat components
â”‚   â”‚   â”‚   â”œâ”€â”€ ChatWindow.jsx # Main chat interface
â”‚   â”‚   â”‚   â””â”€â”€ Message.jsx    # Message bubbles
â”‚   â”‚   â”œâ”€â”€ App.jsx           # Main app component
â”‚   â”‚   â””â”€â”€ index.css         # Tailwind styles
â”‚   â”œâ”€â”€ index.html
â”‚   â””â”€â”€ package.json
â””â”€â”€ server/                   # Node.js Backend
    â”œâ”€â”€ knowledge_base.md     # AI knowledge source
    â”œâ”€â”€ .env                 # Environment variables
    â”œâ”€â”€ server.js            # Express server
    â”œâ”€â”€ scraper.js           # Notion content scraper
    â””â”€â”€ package.json

    
      
    

      
    

    
  
ðŸš€ Quick Start
Prerequisites

Node.js (v16 or higher)
npm or yarn
OpenAI API key (get from OpenAI Platform)

1. Install Dependencies
# Install server dependencies
cd server
npm install

# Install client dependencies
cd ../client
npm install
    
      
    

      
    

    
  
2. Configure OpenAI API

Get your OpenAI API key from OpenAI Platform
Edit server/.env and add your API key:

OPENAI_API_KEY=sk-your-actual-openai-api-key-here
    
      
    

      
    

    
  
3. Run the Application
Terminal 1 - Start the Backend:
cd server
npm start
    
      
    

      
    

    
  
âœ… Server runs on http://localhost:3001
Terminal 2 - Start the Frontend:
cd client
npm run dev
    
      
    

      
    

    
  
âœ… Client runs on http://localhost:5173
4. Test Your AI Chatbot

Open your browser to http://localhost:5173
Ask questions like:

"What are the opening hours?"
"Tell me about norminette"
"How do I find housing?"
"What scholarships are available?"



ðŸ“š Knowledge Base Management
Option 1: Manual Content Addition
Edit server/knowledge_base.md directly with your content:
# 42 Heilbronn Knowledge Base

## Campus Information
- Opening hours: 24/7
- Location: [Your campus address]
- Contact: hello@42heilbronn.de

## Coding Standards
- Norminette rules and requirements
- Project submission guidelines
- Code quality standards
    
      
    

      
    

    
  
Option 2: Comprehensive Data Scraping (Recommended)
Use the advanced scraper to automatically gather data from multiple sources:
cd scrapers
node run-scraper.js
    
      
    

      
    

    
  
What it does:

ðŸ” Web Search: Automatically searches for 42 Heilbronn information
ðŸŒ Website Scraping: Scrapes official websites and relevant sources
ðŸ“‹ Notion Integration: Opens Safari for manual Notion content
ðŸ’¾ Auto-Update: Updates your knowledge base with all data

Benefits:

âœ… Comprehensive: Gets data from multiple sources automatically
âœ… Smart: Uses web search to find relevant information
âœ… Flexible: Combines automated and manual methods
âœ… Organized: Structures data for optimal AI performance

Option 3: Manual Content Addition
Edit server/knowledge_base.md directly with your content:
# 42 Heilbronn Knowledge Base

## Campus Information
- Opening hours: 24/7
- Location: [Your campus address]
- Contact: hello@42heilbronn.de
    
      
    

      
    

    
  
ðŸŽ¨ Customization
Styling the Chat Interface
Colors and Themes:

Edit client/src/index.css for global styles
Modify client/src/components/ChatWindow.jsx for chat layout
Update client/src/components/Message.jsx for message styling

Example customizations:
/* Custom gradient background */
body {
  background: linear-gradient(135deg, #667eea 0%, #764ba2 100%);
}

/* Custom message bubbles */
.message-user {
  background: linear-gradient(135deg, #42b883, #35495e);
}
    
      
    

      
    

    
  
AI Behavior
Modify AI responses in server/server.js:
const systemPrompt = `You are a specialized AI assistant for 42 Heilbronn students.
- ONLY answer questions about 42 Heilbronn, coding, campus life
- Redirect general questions to Google
- Be helpful and friendly but stay focused on 42 topics`;
    
      
    

      
    

    
  
ðŸ”§ Development
Available Scripts
Server:
npm start          # Start production server
node server.js     # Alternative start method
    
      
    

      
    

    
  
Client:
npm run dev        # Development with hot reload
npm run build      # Build for production
npm run preview    # Preview production build
    
      
    

      
    

    
  
API Endpoints

GET /api/health - Server health check
GET /api/knowledge-base - View current knowledge base
POST /api/chat - Chat with the AI

Environment Variables
Server (.env):
OPENAI_API_KEY=sk-your-key-here    # Required: Your OpenAI API key
PORT=3001                          # Optional: Server port (default: 3001)
    
      
    

      
    

    
  
ðŸ› Troubleshooting
Common Issues
1. "OpenAI API key not configured"
# Check your .env file
cat server/.env
# Should show: OPENAI_API_KEY=sk-your-actual-key
    
      
    

      
    

    
  
2. "Failed to process chat request"

âœ… Check OpenAI API key is valid
âœ… Ensure you have credits in your OpenAI account
âœ… Check server console for error details

3. Client not connecting to server

âœ… Verify server is running on port 3001
âœ… Check browser console for network errors
âœ… Ensure both servers are running

4. Knowledge base not updating

âœ… Restart server after updating knowledge_base.md
âœ… Check file permissions
âœ… Verify markdown format is correct

Debug Commands
# Check server health
curl http://localhost:3001/api/health

# View knowledge base content
curl http://localhost:3001/api/knowledge-base

# Check server logs
cd server && npm start
    
      
    

      
    

    
  
ðŸš€ Deployment
Local Development

Both servers run locally
Perfect for development and testing

Production Deployment

Deploy server to cloud platform (Heroku, Vercel, etc.)
Deploy client to static hosting (Netlify, Vercel, etc.)
Update API URLs in client code
Set environment variables in production

Docker Deployment
# Dockerfile example
FROM node:18
WORKDIR /app
COPY server/package*.json ./
RUN npm install
COPY server/ .
EXPOSE 3001
CMD ["npm", "start"]

Fast Response: Optimized for quick AI responses

ðŸ”’ Security

API Key Protection: Never commit .env files
Input Validation: Sanitized user inputs
Rate Limiting: Consider adding for production
CORS Configuration: Properly configured for development

### https://www.notion.so/42heilbronn/Sanctions-2105cefbe7fa80ed841fe03fc47a14f7?pvs=25

**URL:** https://www.notion.so/42heilbronn/Sanctions-2105cefbe7fa80ed841fe03fc47a14f7?pvs=25

**Content:**

Skip to content42 Heilbronn's NotionSearchInboxSharedðŸ“šStudent WikiExplore more of NotionJoin as member to collaborateJoin or create workspaceðŸ“šStudent Wikiâ‰ï¸FAQsðŸ“šGerman tax returnEdited Nov 6, 2024ðŸ“šGerman tax returnOwnerSteve KillianVerificationVerifiedTagsEmptyAdd headings to create a table of contents. Learn more.ðŸ’¡DisclaimerThe following text is no official tax advice. It is an extract from a student message on Slack.Please do not ask us any tax related questions! We are not trained for this. We are just having this information here because we think it could be really helpful and beneficial for our students.sreinhol gave some really good insights:sreinhol 20.10.2022https://42born2code.slack.com/archives/C025A50ATK3/p1666266206280279Hey everyone! I thought I give you guys a little heads up on your personal German income tax return. I know a lot of people are somehow afraid to file a tax return or just don't know that they could get some money back when they do one. Especially among the people here at 42 it might be beneficial to file a tax return. Probably the German student here know that already but maybe not our foreign student.-> You could declare a lot of costs (moving costs, commuting costs, books etc. - the Heilbronn tax office approved these costs in my case). For this there a two cases: 1. You came to 42 as your first education (no Bachelor or "Ausbildung") before or 2. you came to 42 as part of a second education.1. In this case you can declare your costs as Special expenses (Sonderausgaben). This will only have an effect if you earn money in Germany above the basic tax-free amount (Grundfreibetrag).2. In this case you can declare your costs as income-related expenses (Werbungskosten). It will either be deducted from your income directly if you earn money here or if you don't have any income you can forward these costs to the next years and accumulate these costs until you earn money here and then you can deduct it. This means that even if you don't have any income and 42 is your second education you can claim these costs.I hope that gives you a good overview but keep in mind that all of that is really special to every case. (We have a lot of exceptions in the German tax law). But nowadays we have some really good helpers on the market as "taxfix" for example. Also if you have more questions about your tax return you can hit me up, I used to be a tax consultant and I can maybe help you.Overview (09/11/22):German tax return for students.pdf51.7KBPresentation Tax Seminar Steuerseminar 42 .pdf4914.4KBwindow.LOCALE_SETUP=void 0,window.LOCALE_SETUP_P=Promise.resolve()(()=>{try{window.addEventListener("error",(function(e){if(e.target&&(e.target instanceof HTMLScriptElement||e.target instanceof HTMLLinkElement&&"stylesheet"===e.target.rel)){var t=e.target instanceof HTMLScriptElement?"script":"stylesheet",r=e.target.src||e.target.href;console.error("Resource Sentinel noted a failed resource load of type",t,r),fetch("https://http-inputs-notion.splunkcloud.com/services/collector/raw",{method:"POST",headers:{"Content-Type":"text/plain; charset=utf-8",Authorization:"Splunk EA76605A-F565-4B17-A496-34435622A1EB"},mode:"cors",keepalive:!0,body:JSON.stringify({environment:"production",level:"error",from:"resourceSentinel",type:"resourceLoadFailure",error:{message:`Failed to load "${t}" resource`,miscDataString:r}}),priority:"low"}).catch(e=>{console.error("Resource Sentinel failed to send error to Splunk",e)})}}),!0),console.info("Resource Sentinel initialized...")}catch(e){console.error("Resource Sentinel failed to initialize",e)}})()__notion_html_async.push("bootData",{"userId":"284d872b-594c-812b-983e-00023353d1a4","spaceId":"10ec54f0-7d84-413b-b0dd-14cc9a964e80","pageId":"bd8d9874-f44e-4b04-b8ee-2b1da006e5e4"})__notion_html_async.push("ready",!0)__notion_html_async.push("bootReady",true)__notion_html_async.push("serverSidePrefetchDataPending",false)__notion_html_async.push("serverSidePrefetchData",null)__notion_html_async.push("statsigResults",null)__notion_html_async.push("statsigResultsMetadata",null)__notion_html_async.push("requiredRedirectMetadata",{"pageId":"bd8d9874-f44e-4b04-b8ee-2b1da006e5e4","requiresRedirect":false})__notion_html_async.push(null,null)

### https://www.notion.so/42heilbronn/Double-Degree-42-HHN-79a82efba351416cbd9739efd86706cc?pvs=25

**URL:** https://www.notion.so/42heilbronn/Double-Degree-42-HHN-79a82efba351416cbd9739efd86706cc?pvs=25

Skip to content42 Heilbronn's NotionSearchInboxSharedðŸ“šStudent WikiExplore more of NotionJoin as member to collaborateJoin or create workspaceðŸ“šStudent WikiðŸ‘·â€â™€ï¸Internships Wiki V2              (Work Experience)Edited Aug 11ðŸ‘·â€â™€ï¸2 backlinksInternships Wiki V2              (Work Experience)OwnerMMarkus HagnerVerificationUntil December 31, 2025TagsEmptyðŸ’¡In this page you will be able to find all the information about internships in 42, how do they work, what do we need from you and more!Table of contentsTable of contentsWhat is a 42 internship?Am I ready to start applying?Applying to internshipsPreparing for internshipI secured an internship! What are the next steps?What should I know about the internship and what happens after?Scholarships and internshipsVisa and internshipResourcesWhat is a 42 internship?After youâ€™re done with the last circle of the core curriculum (in other words done with ft_trascendence) you need to get experience in the real world. In order to do this 42 requires you to work at a company so that you can tests your skills!There are 3 types of internships that could be valid for 42:ðŸ‘©â€ðŸ’»Full time internship ðŸ§‘â€ðŸ’»Part-time internship ðŸ‘©â€ðŸ’»Startup internship Inside of each page you can find more information on how the internships work, what are the requirements and what are the next steps.Am I ready to start applying?Students are ready to apply for internships when they are almost done with the core curriculum. You can consider youâ€™re almost done when youâ€™re 2 months before your Common Core ETA. No matter if you are in the Pace system or not you are ready for applying when only missing 1 project of circle 5 or the exam of circle 5. In order to get into the internships channel on slack and have access to the complete list of jobs and internships (pinned at the channel), please fill out the following Typeform. Additionally you will receive an invite to the CampusFounders Job_Board.and receive your official â€œReady for Internship Iâ€ certificate. Thats the point to start applying.Before this time you should not be applying for internships. The main reasons for this are:You will probably find an internship before youâ€™re done with the core curriculum, and if this happens you wonâ€™t be able to use that internship as a 42 internship meaning that it wonâ€™t count as if you were done with the core curriculumIt is only after youâ€™re done with the core curriculum that we can assure you will have all the necessary skills to complete your job, and if we start having students going to internships before they are done with the core curriculum, this can severely damage the reputation of 42 HN and therefore make companies stop hiring our students.You will probably not have the best of the experiences in your job since you will probably not be fully prepared for it.Applying to internshipsAs we all know in 42 everyone is responsible of their own progress and internships are exactly the same. Youâ€™re responsible on creating your CV, updating your Linkedin profile, applying to companies, etc. So please donâ€™t expect someone to be reminding you about what you should be doing.We (42 Staff Members) are always happy to help but we are not going to be pushing you to get an internship. Nevertheless we are here to help and if you have any questions or ideas please feel free to reach out to us and if we can we will be more than happy to assist you. From our side we are talking to a lot of companies to make sure that they know what 42 is and it is easier for you to apply.When applying at one of our partner companies please send your â€œReady for Internship Iâ€ certificate together with your application. Also make sure you have your notifications on for the internships channel on slack, there we will be posting any update.Preparing for internshipWith your studies and completion of the core curriculum projects, you have acquired all the necessary skills to successfully launch your career.We are aware that many companies today utilize multiple programming languages, such as Python, JS/TS, Java, Rust, Go, to name just a few. Since you will likely need to work with one of these languages, we aim to provide you with the opportunity to gain foundational knowledge. This means that as soon as you are ready for the internship and have received the official 42 Heilbronn internship certificate, you will automatically be invited (at the end of the month in which you received the certificate) to participate in the following optional Cisco Courses:Python Essentials 1Python Essentials 2JavaScript Essentials 1Additionally, we will progressively introduce different learning tutorials to the curriculum, starting with Python, which you can engage with on a voluntary basis. The Python Piscine will be made available in the holy graph as soon as you complete circle 5.I secured an internship! What are the next steps?First of all congrats on securing an internship! This is an amazing milestone on anyones career, and it shouldnâ€™t be taken lightly. Even though securing an internship is a huge step it is only the beginning, now comes doing the real work, so get ready and follow this instructions to make sure youâ€™re all set to go:Make sure your internship offer fulfills the minimum requirements for its type (you can find more information here: ðŸ‘©â€ðŸ’»Full time internship, ðŸ§‘â€ðŸ’»Part-time internship and ðŸ‘©â€ðŸ’»Startup internship)Make sure that youâ€™re allowed to work for the whole duration of your internship. If you have a visa, please take a look into: Visa and internship Once youâ€™re sure your internships fulfills the criteria for an internship in 42, you have to fill out the typeform in order for your project to be open.Ask Markus to open the internship project for you in case it is not openNote: We wonâ€™t open up the project unless you have submitted the previous TypeformNow follow this instructions in order to setup your internship on intra: ðŸ¤“Intranet Internships Setup Finish up your core curriculum fast to be ready to leave!What should I know about the internship and what happens after?During your internship and after it you should concentrate on the job youâ€™re doing, 42 will contact you from time to time to get your feedback on the work youâ€™re doing and also contact your supervisor to get feedback from company side. This will help us to learn. When starting your internship we would highly appreciate if you inform your supervisor that he will receive a short surveys from â€œhello@42heilbronn.deâ€ every 2 month during your internship. Other than that there are only 3 things to remember for 42:Company evaluations on intranetMid EvaluationEnd EvaluationPeer evaluationYou will haveÂ three evaluation momentsÂ during your internship time. This consists ofÂ two evaluations with the company: one midway evaluation that happens halfway through your internship and one final evaluation at the end.To make scheduling more easy for your internship company we recommend to forward the evaluation dates at the beginning of your internship to your company contact and/or supervisor.TheÂ final evaluationÂ to validate your internship project consists of a video that will beÂ evaluated by your peers or a presentation that you will hold in front of your peers.Mid Evaluation:Is planned after you validate your internship contract.Will happen exactly half-way through your internship. Your supervisor will receive an automatic email on the scheduled day with a link to an evaluation form. The evaluation can also be done a few days later. End Evaluation:Will happen during the final week of your internshipYour supervisor will receive an automatic email on the scheduled day with a link to an evaluation form. The evaluation can also be done a few days later. 
Pro tip:Â make sure your supervisor fills it in while youâ€™re still in the company, otherwise theyâ€™ll probably forget about it and you will be stuck.Peer Evaluation Video:You have to make a video to present/show what youâ€™ve learned. Read the subject to know how to do the video and what content to display.Â You need to make sure that youâ€™re not sharing anything thatâ€™s confidential.Â Watch the explanatory video for more information!!!This evaluation is expected to be done on campus!Internship presentation:Instead of the peer evaluation video you can do a presentation in front of your peers.
Check the corresponding Notion page for more info: âŒšInternship Presentation Scholarships and internshipsIn case you have an active scholarship, you should send an email to hello@42heilbronn.de as soon as you can in order to define when are you leaving for the scholarship since scholarships need to suspended while youâ€™re in an internship. This will allow us to provide scholarships to more students! Scholarships are always paid at the end of the month for the next month. In the case of an internship, you only receive your salary at the end of the month. Please note that one or more months may not be covered by the scholarship.Visa and internshipInternships for students from third countries (non-EU 42 students):In general, persons from third countries who do not have a residence permit are not allowed to work in the EU. For 42 students there is an exception for the internship at the end of the core curriculum. For this purpose, at least five weeks (not a guaranteed time frame but most of the requests were finished in that time frame) before the internship, the application form filled in by the employer must be sent to the AuslÃ¤nderbehÃ¶rde by Bocal. The application form can be downloaded below. As soon as you get the document back from your internship company please forward it to bocal including your contract using hello@42heilbronn.de. Only documents send by bocal will be accepted by the AuslÃ¤nderbehÃ¶rde. Please be aware that if you will not live in the city of Heilbronn during the course of the internship this work around will not apply. You will need to contact the respective foreigners authority in the city you will be living in. For further information about visa check back with the arrival guide. Anlage 4_Erklarung zum Besch aÌˆftigungsverhaÌˆltnis_final (4).pdf3630.1KBResources42 HN Partners job offers:42 Heilbronn Internship job offers are accessible for all students. Please keep in mind that you will only be accepted as an intern at partner companies if you send your â€œinternship ready certificateâ€. We like you to focus on your studies and start applying for internships when you are ready and close to be finished with the core curriculum.   Heilbronn, Germany  From your IP address  â€¢ Update locationConversation with Gemini You're a entrepreneurship and a senior fullstack dev  I have this idea of bulding a chatbot / AI for 42 heilbronn school in Heilbronn Germany, to help new pisciners and students with their general questions, tell me in steps how to make this wrk and what you think its best, a website for this or what? Show thinkingExcellent idea. A well-designed AI assistant could be incredibly valuable for the fast-paced, high-pressure environment of the piscine and the ongoing curriculum at 42 Heilbronn.As a senior dev and entrepreneur, my advice is to start with a web-based chatbot as an MVP (Minimum Viable Product). It's the fastest way to build, test, and get feedback, while offering the most flexibility for future expansion.Hereâ€™s a step-by-step plan to make it work.Phase 1: The Lean MVP ðŸš€The goal here is speed and validation. You want to build something useful in a weekend or a week, not months.Step 1: Gather Your Knowledge Base (The AI's Brain)This is the most critical step. Your AI is useless without the right information. Forget complex tech for a moment and focus on the data.Create a simple document (a Markdown file in a Git repo is perfect).Brainstorm every question a pisciner asks:Logistics: "Where is the coffee machine?", "What are the cluster opening hours?", "How do I report a broken chair?"Curriculum: "What is norminette?", "How does moulinette work?", "What's the deadline for Exam 00?", "Can you explain the libft project?"Social/Rules: "Are there any student clubs?", "What are the rules for the nap room?", "Where do people go for lunch?"Get Answers: Ask current students and staff (the "Bocal") to help you answer these questions accurately. The official 42 Heilbronn resources are your source of truth.Step 2: Choose the Right (and Easiest) Tech StackYou're a full-stack dev, so you can handle this. The key is to use tools that get you to a working prototype fast.The "Brain" (LLM): Use the OpenAI Assistants API. It's designed for exactly this. You can upload your knowledge base file directly, and it handles the complex process of "Retrieval-Augmented Generation" (RAG) for you. This means the AI will use your document to answer questions, preventing it from making things up. You'll need an API key (APIkeyâ€‹).Backend: A simple Node.js server with Express.js. Its only job is to receive messages from your frontend, securely call the OpenAI API with your key, and stream the response back. This is crucialâ€”never expose your API key on the frontend.Frontend: A basic web page. You can use React (via Vite) for a fast setup. For the chat interface itself, don't build it from scratch. Use a pre-built library like react-chatbot-kit to save a massive amount of time on UI development.Step 3: Build & DeploySetup Backend: Create an Express server with one endpoint (e.g., /ask). This endpoint takes a user's question, forwards it to your OpenAI Assistant, and returns the answer.Setup Frontend: Create a simple React app with your chosen chatbot UI component. When a user sends a message, make a fetch request to your /ask endpoint on your backend.Deploy: Get it online immediately. Use services like Vercel (for the frontend) and Render (for the Node.js backend). They have generous free tiers and are incredibly easy to set up with a GitHub repository.You now have a working MVP. Share the link with a few friends at 42 and get feedback.Phase 2: Scale & Integrate ðŸ§ Once your MVP is validated and people find it useful, it's time to make it truly powerful.Step 1: Deep Integration with the 42 EcosystemThis is the game-changer. Use the 42 Intra API.Personalization: Allow students to log in via their 42 account (OAuth). Now your chatbot can answer personalized questions like:"What's my correction point count?""Who are my evaluators for my current project?""When is my next exam?"Real-time Info: Pull data on project deadlines, Holy Graph updates, and campus events directly from the source.Step 2: Upgrade Your Knowledge BaseA single file won't scale.Vector Database: Move your knowledge base from a text file to a vector database like Pinecone, ChromaDB, or Supabase pgvector. This allows for much faster and more semantically accurate searching over a huge amount of data. You can feed it the entire 42 documentation, student-written guides, etc.CMS for Updates: Create a simple admin interface (or use a headless CMS like Strapi) so that authorized people (maybe even trusted students or staff) can update the bot's knowledge without needing to code.Step 3: Proactive FeaturesDon't just answer questionsâ€”anticipate needs.Notifications: "Heads up, your project deadline is in 48 hours."Event Reminders: "Don't forget the workshop on Docker happening in Cluster 1 at 3 PM today."Platform Choice: Website vs. OthersHereâ€™s a breakdown of why a website is the best starting point.Website (The Winner for an MVP) ðŸ†Pros:Universal Access: Works on any device with a browser. No installation needed. Perfect for a quick check on a cluster Mac or a personal phone.Easy to Share: Just a URL. You can create a QR code and stick it all over the cluster.Full Control: You own the user experience, branding, and feature set.Embeddable: You can later offer the chatbot as a widget to be embedded in other community sites.Cons:Lacks the "push notification" power of a native app (though web push notifications are possible).Slack/Discord BotThis is a strong contender for a Phase 2 feature, but not for the start.Pros:Meets Users Where They Are: The 42 Heilbronn community likely lives on Slack or Discord.Excellent for Notifications: Great for pushing announcements.Cons:Limited UI: You're constrained by the chat platform's UI elements."Noise" Factor: The bot's valuable answers can get lost in a busy channel.Discovery: New students might not know which channel to find the bot in.Native Mobile App (iOS/Android)Avoid this for now.Pros:Best User Experience: Smooth, fast, and fully integrated with the OS (e.g., push notifications).Cons:Massive Overkill for an MVP: You'd have to build, maintain, and deploy two separate codebases (or use a cross-platform framework, which has its own complexities).High Barrier to Entry: Forcing a pisciner to download an app from the App Store just to ask a question is a huge friction point. They will likely just ask a human instead.Start with the website, make it awesome, and then build a Slack/Discord bot that hooks into the same backend logic. Good luck! ### **1. Backend Details (`/server`)**

**File: `server/package.json`**
- Dependencies: `express`, `openai`, `cors`, `dotenv`, `fs` (built-in).

**File: `server/.env`**
- Create a placeholder for the OpenAI API key: `OPENAI_API_KEY="YOUR_API_KEY_HERE"`

**File: `server/.gitignore`**
- Add `node_modules` and `.env`.

**File: `server/knowledge_base.md`**
- Create this file and populate it with placeholder markdown content. Include a comment at the top: `<!-- Export your Notion pages to Markdown and paste the content here. This file will serve as the AI's primary knowledge source. -->`
- Example Content:
  ```markdown
  # 42 Heilbronn - Student FAQ

  ## Logistics
  - **Opening Hours**: The cluster is open 24/7.
  - **Coffee**: The main coffee machine is located in the lounge area on the ground floor. It is free of charge.

  ## Piscine
  - **Norminette**: A coding standard checker used at 42. All projects must comply with the norm. Run `norminette` on your files to check them.
  - **Moulinette**: The automated grading system that will evaluate your projects. It is merciless.
File: server/server.jsTechnology: Node.js with Express.Setup:Import express, openai, cors, dotenv, and fs.Configure dotenv to load environment variables.Initialize an Express app and enable cors and the express.json() middleware.Knowledge Loading:On server start, synchronously read the entire knowledge_base.md file into a string variable called knowledgeBase.System Prompt Construction:Create a systemPrompt string that combines instructions with the loaded knowledge. This is crucial for Retrieval-Augmented Generation (RAG).JavaScriptconst systemPrompt = `You are a helpful AI assistant for new students and pisciners at 42 Heilbronn. Your name is 'CADET-BOT'. Answer the user's questions accurately and concisely based ONLY on the context provided below. Do not use any external knowledge. If the answer is not found in the context, politely state that you don't have information on that topic.

--- CONTEXT ---
${knowledgeBase}
--- END CONTEXT ---
`;
API Endpoint:Create a POST endpoint at /api/chat.Logic:Get the user's message from the request body.Instantiate the OpenAI client using the API key from .env.Make a call to the OpenAI Chat Completions API (client.chat.completions.create).Payload:model: "gpt-4-turbo"messages: An array containing two messages:{ role: 'system', content: systemPrompt }{ role: 'user', content: message }Extract the assistant's reply from the response.Send the reply back to the client as JSON: { "reply": "..." }.Include robust error handling with a try...catch block.Server Start:Listen on a port (e.g., 3001) specified in an environment variable or defaulting. Log a confirmation message to the console.2. Frontend Details (/client)Setup: Use Vite to scaffold a React project with SWC.Styling: Use Tailwind CSS. Generate a tailwind.config.js and a postcss.config.js, and include the @tailwind directives in src/index.css.File: client/src/App.jsxShould contain the main layout: a dark background, a centered container for the chat interface, a title like "42 Heilbronn AI Assistant", and render the <ChatWindow /> component.File: client/src/components/ChatWindow.jsxThis is the core UI component.State:messages: An array of message objects, e.g., [{ sender: 'user', text: 'Hello' }, { sender: 'ai', text: 'Hi!' }].isLoading: A boolean to show a loading indicator while waiting for the AI's response.UI:A message display area that maps over the messages state and renders a <Message /> component for each one. This area should be scrollable.An input form at the bottom with a text input and a "Send" button.Functionality:An async function handleSendMessage that is called on form submission.Logic of handleSendMessage:Prevent default form submission.Get the user's message from the input. If it's empty, do nothing.Update the messages state to include the user's new message.Set isLoading to true.Make a POST request to the backend's /api/chat endpoint, sending the user's message in the body.When the response is received, create a new AI message object.Update the messages state again, adding the AI's reply.Set isLoading to false.Clear the input field.File: client/src/components/Message.jsxA simple component that takes a message object as a prop.It should render the message text with different styling based on whether the sender is 'user' or 'ai'. For example, user messages are on the right with a blue background, and AI messages are on the left with a gray background.
---

### Your Next Steps After Generation

1.  **Install Dependencies:** Run `npm install` inside the `/client` directory and then again inside the `/server` directory.
2.  **Set API Key:** Open `/server/.env` and replace `"YOUR_API_KEY_HERE"` with your actual OpenAI API key.
3.  **Populate Knowledge Base:** Open `/server/knowledge_base.md`. Go to your Notion pages, export them as Markdown, and paste the content into this file. The more detailed it is, the smarter your bot will be.
4.  **Run the Application:**
    * In one terminal, navigate to `/server` and run `node server.js`.
    * In a second terminal, navigate to `/client` and run `npm run dev`.
5.  **Open the App:** Your browser should open to the Vite development server (usually `http://localhost:5173`). You should see your chatbot interface, ready to go!
 how to export notions from a workplace, thats not mine of course Show thinkingThis is a very important and sensitive question. As an AI assistant, and in my role as your "senior dev/entrepreneur" advisor, I must be very clear about this:You absolutely should not, and technically cannot, export data from a Notion workspace that you do not own or have been given explicit export permissions for.Attempting to access or export data without authorization is a serious issue for several reasons:Ethical & Legal: It's a violation of trust and privacy. In Germany, this falls under strict data privacy laws (DSGVO/GDPR). Unauthorized data access can have significant legal consequences.Intellectual Property: The content within the 42 Heilbronn Notion workspace is the property of the organization.Notion's Terms of Service: Bypassing security or access controls is a direct violation of Notion's policies and could lead to account suspension.Technical Barriers: Notion is designed to prevent this. Export functionality is tied to the permissions of your user account. If you're not an admin or haven't been given full access, the options will be disabled.The Right Approach: The Entrepreneur's WayYour goal is to get the data to help the community. The professional and correct way to do this is not to find a technical workaround, but to build a bridge and get official collaboration.Here is a step-by-step plan to get the data you need, the right way.Step 1: Identify the Owner(s)Find out who manages the Notion workspace. It is likely the Bocal (the staff) or a specific person in charge of student resources.Step 2: Prepare Your PitchYou are building a valuable tool for the school, for free. "I am developing an AI-powered chatbot to help new and current students answer common questions about 42 Heilbronn."What is the benefit for them? "This will reduce the number of repetitive questions the staff receives, help pisciners feel more supported, and serve as a 24/7 accessible resource for everyone."What do you need? "To ensure the chatbot is accurate and trustworthy, I need to use the official information currently stored in the school's Notion workspace as its knowledge base."How will it work? "I can use a one-time export of the relevant pages, or, for a more advanced solution, we could use the Notion API for read-only access to keep the information automatically up-to-date."Step 3: Make the Formal RequestDraft a professional email or schedule a meeting.Here is a template you can adapt:Subject: Proposal for a 42 Heilbronn AI Assistant & Collaboration RequestHello [Name of Bocal/Admin],My name is [Your Name], and I am a student here at 42 Heilbronn.I am currently developing a project to benefit the entire student community: an AI-powered chatbot designed to instantly answer common questions for pisciners and students. [Your Intra Login]How Exporting Works (When You Have Permission)Once you have permission, the process is straightforward. The workspace admin can do one of the following for you:Option 1: Manual Export (Best for MVP)This is the simplest method. The admin navigates to the page(s) you need, and does the following:Clicks the three-dot menu (...) in the top-right corner of a Notion page.Selects "Export".Chooses "Markdown & CSV" as the export format. This is perfect for your knowledge_base.md file.Includes subpages if necessary.Clicks "Export" and sends you the resulting ZIP file.Option 2: Workspace Export (Admin Only)If they want to give you everything, an admin can export the entire workspace from "Settings & Members" > "Settings" > "Export all workspace content". This creates a ZIP file of all pages.Option 3: Granting You Access (The Collaborative Way)They could create a specific role for you or share the relevant pages with your Notion account with "Can view" or "Full access" permissions, which would then allow you to perform the export yourself.Option 4: Using the Notion API (The Pro Way for Phase 2)For your scaling phase, you could request to build a Notion API integration. This would allow your application to fetch data programmatically and always be up-to-date. This is more complex but is the most sustainable solution.By approaching this through official channels, you not only get the data you need but also build credibility, gain potential allies for your project, and ensure you are creating a tool that is approved and supported by the school.
